g.text: disease (COPD), and lung cancer. Additional ozone-related
mortality due to respiratory problems is estimated to be 8,900
(95% CI: 2,300 to 4,700) people per year.
Discussion
Our regional modeling indicates that climate change will exac-
erbate future air pollution mortality in China. This finding is
generally consistent with previous studies despite differences in
modeled time periods, scenarios, regions, climate-chemistry
models used, and population and baseline mortality projections
(25, 26). For example, climate change is also expected to nega-
tively affect air quality in the United States, but compared with
the United States, we project roughly an order of magnitude
more climate-induced air pollution-related deaths in China (27).
Our results also go beyond previous studies in revealing the
outsized role of more intense climate extremes in future climate-
driven air pollution mortality in China. In total, increases in
future atmospheric stagnation events contribute 68% to the
climate-driven increase in PM
concentration and 39% to the
increase in air pollution-related mortality (incorporating a much
smaller effect on ozone concentrations) (
SI Appendix
, Fig. S6
These estimates bear out the suggestions of previous studies that
increasingly frequent stagnation events could negatively impact
human health (6, 14). Although less important than stagnation
due to fewer event days, increases in future heat waves have a
large effect on ozone concentrations, totaling 14% of the
climate-driven ozone increase we project and 6%of the increase
in air pollution-related mortality (
SI Appendix
, Fig. S6
). In con-
trast, increases in future heavy precipitation events reduce 6%of
the climate-driven air pollution-related mortality (
SI Appendix
Fig. S6
). Our results reveal the large effect of these climate ex-
tremes on PM
and the less pronounced effect on ozone (
SI
Appendix
, Fig. S6
), indicating that PM
increases dramatically
under extreme conditions, while the ozone increases might be
prevalent under both extreme and mean conditions due to cli-
mate warming. Given the substantial contribution from extreme
weather events to the modeled increase in air pollution (espe-
cially PM
) and mortality, as well as the dominant role that
extreme weather events play in the increase in extreme haze
events, we suggest that extreme weather events may be an im-
portant mechanism by which climate change will affect air
quality, and especially PM
Our findings here are subject to several important limitations
and sources of uncertainty. First, given the high-resolution and
computationally intensive methodology, our simulations are
limited to a single climate-chemistry model. However, our find-
ing that future climate change is likely to exacerbate China
s air
pollution is broadly consistent with numerous previous studies
11, 25, 26, 28, 29) that used independent models and meth-
ods. In particular, several studies have indicated that weather
conditions conducive to extreme haze will likely occur at a higher
frequency in China under climate change as a result of large-
scale circulation changes caused by the Arctic sea ice decline
and the weakening of the East Asian winter monsoon (7
9). Yet,
the original air stagnation index adopted by Cai et al. (8) and
Horton et al. (14) does not capture the wintertime frequent haze
events in China (30). By adopting a new air stagnation index
Methods
), we find that stagnation can identify a large fraction of
severe haze events in China (
SI Appendix
, Fig. S5
). The increased
frequency of stagnation events is consistent with the more fre-
quent weather conditions conducive to extreme haze as reported
by previous studies (7
9). Previous studies reveal 3 potential
pathways linking midlatitude weather extremes to Arctic ampli-
fication, including changes in storm tracks, the jet stream, and
planetary waves (9, 31), althoug
h there is not yet consensus re-
garding the Arctic linkages (32). Se
veral studies have suggested that
amplified planetary waves favor weather extremes in midlatitudes
Second, although we evaluate error in our mortality estimates
related to the uncertain integrated exposure responses (i.e.,
uncertainty in the relative risk [RR]; details are provided in
Methods
), our projections assume no change in population size,
age structure, or location. This assumption allows a direct eval-
uation of the effects of climate change apart from any de-
mographic changes. However, in order to assess the potential
sensitivity of our results to this assumption, we conducted further
analyses using scenarios of future population and age structure.
We find that greater vulnerability of China
s aging population
will further increase PM
-related mortality and ozone-related
mortality in 2050 by factors of 1 and 3, respectively (Table 1).
Thus, climate change is likely to increase air pollution mor-
tality in China, and given demographic trends, our estimates of
actual deaths may be an underestimate. The climate penalty
effects on air quality and human health would be larger under a
high climate scenario (e.g., RCP8.5 in 2100, which could be
analyzed in future studies). They are more pronounced in
densely populated and already polluted areas of China and in
heavily polluted winters. Our results indicate that climate change
is likely to increase the risk of severe pollution events in China,
and thus alter the level of pollution control required to meet air
quality targets.
This study provides quantitative assessments and important
insights regarding the links between climate extremes, future air
quality, and public health. Our finding that extreme weather
events may be an important mechanism by which climate change
will affect air quality, which provides improved understanding of
the impacts as well as the underlying mechanisms, has implica-
tions for those studying climatic influence on such extreme
events, for air quality modelers, and for policy makers seeking to
mitigate future harms. Our results bear out the suggestion that
increasingly frequent extreme events such as atmospheric stag-
nation and heat waves could negatively impact air quality, es-
pecially during extreme air pollution episodes. Policy makers and
the public are not primarily concerned with average air quality,
but with periodic episodes when air pollution is especially bad,
which may have disproportionate impacts on human health, and
are thus a major focus of clean air policies. For policy makers,
one of the most important aspects of air quality management is
therefore the mitigation of extreme air pollution episodes. If, as
we find, climate change will significantly worsen such extreme

-related mortality Ozone-related mortality

Future population and current baseline mortality rates 43,800 40,800
Current population and future baseline mortality rates 7,200 7,400
Future population and future baseline mortality rates 27,000 35,000

(2046 to 2050) years. The base results assume no change in population and baseline mortality rates. We conducted further sensitivity analyses using f
uture
population and future baseline mortality rates.
